image.altText: A sign that says 'Moylan Grain Silos'.

items.synopsis: The owner of a silo manufacturing plant remembers the WA father who was fatally shot as a "fantastic fella", while saying he finds it hard to "resent" the co-worker who pulled the trigger.

title.children: 'Utter disbelief': Owner of business at centre of WA fatal shooting speaks out after losing two workers in one day

image.altText: Chart showing a huge rain front across south west WA

items.synopsis: Severe weather lashes large parts of Western Australia, as strong winds and heavy rain cause havoc across Perth and the south west of the state.

title.children: Rain inundates streets, shopping centre as severe weather lashes Perth and South West

image.altText: Qantas planes sit parked at Sydney Airport, with the city's skyline in the background.

items.synopsis: Qantas took a long-running battle with the Transport Workers' Union over sacked staff to the High Court, where the airline today lost its appeal.

title.children: High Court finds Qantas acted illegally when sacking 1,700 ground crew during pandemic

image.altText: A man in a suit with long hair.

items.synopsis: Chris Marco pleads not guilty to accusations he defrauded nine investors out of tens of millions of dollars, amid allegations one individual alone lost $10 million.

title.children: Perth businessman to fight charges he defrauded investors out of $36.5 million

image.altText: West Coast Eagles Chief Executive Officer Trevor Nisbett speaks at a press conference

items.synopsis: One of the biggest names in football in WA, West Coast Eagles CEO Trevor Nisbett, confirms next year will be his last at the club after back-to-back disastrous seasons and intense scrutiny of his position.

title.children: West Coast Eagles CEO Trevor Nisbett to depart club after next AFL season

image.altText: A side shot of a man's face and neck.

items.synopsis: A parliamentary probe investigating links between former cabinet minister Stuart Robert and a Canberra lobbying firm, and the subsequent awarding of government contracts calls on the National Anti-Corruption Commission to investigate the saga.

title.children: Former cabinet minister Stuart Robert referred to national corruption body

image.altText: Serena Williams stands in front of Simona Halep

items.synopsis: Simona Halep is banned for four years after an independent panel found it was "likely" she was guilty of doping, with Serena Williams suggesting the Romanian's previous results should also be investigated.

title.children: Simona Halep is banned from tennis for four years — and Serena Williams wants a 24th major title as a result

image.altText: Photo of sitting stationary on the Sydney airport runway.

items.synopsis: The local share market is trading lower today, following Wall Street's losses. Qantas loses its High Court appeal over the sacking of 1,700 workers during the pandemic. Follow updates in our live blog.

title.children: Qantas issues first-ever apology to workers it illegally sacked during pandemic, ASX in the red led by tech stocks

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The federal government has introduced legislation today that will ban the use of credit cards for online gambling. The ban will also cover the use of cryptocurrency and digital currencies. The Minister for Social Services Amanda Rishworth says it will protect vulnerable Australians. "You can't use your credit card to place a bet for land-based gambling and the same rules should apply for online gambling too." Companies could face fines of up to $235,000 if they don't enforce the new rules. Financial Counselling Australia's (FCA) director of policy and campaigns Lauren Levin says it's a major win in the battle to reduce gambling harm. "Digital currencies can have wild fluctuations in value, so not only do people speculate on their bets, but also on the movement in the digital currency." However, the FCA is disappointed online lotteries won't be included in the ban. "Online lotteries have changed the whole situation, as the danger of losing large sums is now just as high as someone gambling on online sports betting. "There is no good reason for online lotteries to allow people to buy a $10,000 ticket on credit, or for people to enter a $3,000 syndicate on credit. "Gambling is gambling."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: You soon won't be able to gamble online using credit cards

children.content: The federal government has introduced legislation today that will
ban the use of credit cards for online gambling
The ban will also cover the use of cryptocurrency and digital currencies.
The Minister for Social Services Amanda Rishworth says it will protect vulnerable Australians.
"You can't use your credit card to place a bet for land-based gambling and the same rules should apply for online gambling too."
Companies could face
fines of up to $235,000
if they don't enforce the new rules.
Financial Counselling Australia's (FCA) director of policy and campaigns Lauren Levin says
it's a major win in the battle to reduce gambling harm
"Digital currencies can have wild fluctuations in value, so not only do people speculate on their bets, but also on the movement in the digital currency."
However, the FCA is
disappointed online lotteries won't be included in the ban
"Online lotteries have changed the whole situation, as the danger of losing large sums is now just as high as someone gambling on online sports betting.
"There is no good reason for online lotteries to allow people to buy a $10,000 ticket on credit, or for people to enter a $3,000 syndicate on credit.
"Gambling is gambling."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The local share market is still down in the middle of the trading day. The ASX 200 is down -0.8% to 7150 points at 12:20pm AEST. The index has lost 1.4% over the past five days. The All Ordinaries is also down -0.8% to 7344 points. It's looking pretty red across the sectors today as you can see in the ASX chart below. The top movers are: Core Lithium +4.6% Lake Resources +4.4% Capricorn Metals +2.4% Coronado Global Resources +2.5% Liontown Resources +2% The bottom movers: IGO -5.8% (ex dividend) Brambles -3% Medibank Private -2.9% Breville Group -2.9% Allkem -2.8% Don't forget you can get live updates on the major ASX indices here:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX still tracking lower at midday

It's looking pretty red across the sectors today as you can see in the ASX chart below.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A Qantas spokesperson has confirmed the apology included in the airline's statement is the first one it has issued to workers who were affected by the illegal outsourcing decision. Earlier, Qantas released a statement shortly after the verdict that included: "We deeply regret the personal impact the outsourcing decision had on all those affected and we sincerely apologise for that." The ABC has since confirmed with the airline that it is the first time it has officially apologised over the incident.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Qantas issues first-ever apology to workers affected by illegal outsourcing decision

children.content: A Qantas spokesperson has confirmed the apology included in the airline's statement is the first one it has issued to workers who were affected by the illegal outsourcing decision.
Earlier, Qantas released a statement shortly after the verdict that included:
"We deeply regret the personal impact the outsourcing decision had on all those affected and
we sincerely apologise for that."
The ABC has since confirmed with the airline that it is the first time it has officially apologised over the incident.

image.altText: A man in a blue uniform with a hat on sits

items.synopsis: While a temporary two-lane crossing has provided relief during the construction of the new Fitzroy Crossing bridge, it will be closed from today for the wet season.

title.children: Freight companies brace for delays with Fitzroy River crossing down to single lane

image.altText: a woman looks into a camera standing on a walk way

items.synopsis: Halls Creek is grappling with entrenched social issues, including low school attendance and high rates of youth crime, but a chronic housing shortage is frustrating efforts to address these problems.

title.children: Ayesha helps disadvantaged families in a remote town, but a housing crisis could force her to leave

image.altText: An iPhone on display.

items.synopsis: Apple has unveiled its next generation of iPhones — a line-up that will boast better cameras, faster processors, a new charging system and a price hike for the fanciest model.

title.children: Apple rolls out iPhone 15, ditches Lightning charging ports

image.altText: Marcia Langton at a press conference in Parliament House

items.synopsis: The co-architect of the Voice to Parliament says comments she made at a forum in regional Western Australia have been misreported.

title.children: Co-architect of Voice says No camp 'racism' comments 'misreported'

image.altText: Saweetie is wearing a pink sparkly dress with pink bone-like accessories.

items.synopsis: The MTV VMAs are bringing their fair share of the show-stopping fashion you'd expect. Here are the biggest red carpet arrivals and who wore what so far.

title.children: Here are the show-stopping red carpet highlights from this year's MTV VMAs

image.altText: Two young women stand outdoors in a composite photo.

items.synopsis: For many young people, the referendum on the Indigenous Voice to Parliament will mark their first opportunity to vote. So how are they feeling about the vote?

title.children: They'll have to live with the Voice result for longer, so what do young First Nations people think?

image.altText: Bodies wrapped in blankets are placed into a mass grave, an excavator can be seen in upper right corner

items.synopsis: Thousands of people are killed and at least 10,000 are missing in Libya after floods caused by a huge Mediterranean storm that burst dams, swept away buildings and wiped out as much as a quarter of the eastern coastal city of Derna.

title.children: Libya floods wipe out quarter of city, more than 5,000 presumed dead

image.altText: Joe Biden speaking into a microphone in front of an American flag

items.synopsis: Why are Republicans launching an impeachment inquiry into US President Joe Biden, and what will happen from here? This is what we know.

title.children: Why are Republicans trying to impeach Joe Biden — and could it backfire?

image.altText: A snowy white ring surrounds a blue disk galaxy.

items.synopsis: Astronomers have spotted two cosmic oddities that could be exceedingly rare polar ring galaxies in data captured by the powerful ASKAP radio telescope in WA's outback. They say the discovery could help shed more light on the secrets of dark matter.

title.children: Two mysterious, gift-wrapped galaxies spotted by WA radio telescope

image.altText: Illawarra resident shocked after digging up mortar shell in backyard

items.synopsis: A new home owner got the fright of his life after he unearthed a 30-centimetre-long mortar from his backyard. Emergency services, including the Australian Defence Force, blocked off the street to investigate.

title.children: Weekend home renovation turns up a surprise as owner hits buried mortar shell in backyard

image.altText: Two hands holding separate iPhones close to each other, horizontally.

items.synopsis: The details of new products are being leaked months before they're announced. Here's how the tech giants are trying to keep things secret.

title.children: The new iPhone's key features have been known for months — thanks to leakers like Sonny from Melbourne

image.altText: Serhii Bolvinov working

items.synopsis: When Russian forces stormed Izium last year, the Ukrainian city was a hub for torture. One year later, the painstaking work to identify those responsible continues, with a little help from social media.

title.children: Torturers fled the Ukrainian city of Izium a year ago — they left clues about their identity online

image.altText: A young boy, crying, sits on a rock.

items.synopsis: Last week's earthquake destroyed every building in the remote village of Tikekht. Now anger is building as recovery efforts stall and newly orphaned children pick through the rubble with nowhere else to go.

title.children: The Moroccan town wiped off the map in one day

image.altText: man with beard holding bottles

items.synopsis: Chester Smith has sheds full of vintage knick-knacks that have been passed down through the generations, from old cars and tractors to bottles and candlestick telephones.

title.children: Forget Marie Kondo, Chester says his extensive collection of old junk is what really sparks joy

image.altText: a woman holding bunches of native flowers standing in a field

items.synopsis: The co-founder of Grown Not Flown, Nikki Davey, is awarded for her work in creating a digital platform and app to connect micro and small-scale farmers with consumers.

title.children: Tech entrepreneur changing for the better how we buy flowers

image.altText: A Qantas jet and a Jetstar jet sit on the tarmac at Melbourne Airport

items.synopsis: I’m not sure whether I’ve got any unclaimed Qantas flight credits. I haven’t looked, which is exactly what Qantas wants. Separating people determined to get their money from those who give up is a standard business practice, writes Peter Martin

title.children: Making refunds hard is standard practice — but Qantas appears to have added a twist

image.altText: Margherita pizza on a marble bench top with yellow melted cheese, fresh green basil leaves and red tomato sauce.

items.synopsis: Scratch beneath the surface of some of the origin stories of the world's most popular national dishes, and you'll find a big serve of controversy.

title.children: Love ramen, pizza or tacos? Their origins might surprise you

image.altText: A crime scene on a suburban street

items.synopsis: Detectives believe a shooter fired from the road or footpath outside the boy's Endeavour Hills home, striking the teen and leaving him with non-life-threatening injuries.

title.children: Teenage boy shot while asleep in bed in Melbourne's south-east, police say

image.altText: Police and public

items.synopsis: Melbourne's Wesley College leads the tributes for John Haasz, who was killed in the Friday night crash in the city's CBD.

title.children: Melbourne philanthropist killed in Bourke Street incident remembered for 'remarkable life'

image.altText: A person in a school uniform sits on a fat-tyred e-bike.

items.synopsis: Parents say they're driving less and that their kids are enjoying the freedom afforded by e-bikes, but others have voiced concerns about safety.

title.children: Fat bikes boom in popularity in Sydney, leading to dozens of complaints

image.altText: A bird in a tree

items.synopsis: A rare and endangered bird that fashions drumsticks from wood and seed pods also has a flair for individual design, according to Australian National University researchers at work in Far North Queensland.

title.children: Rare cockatoo known as the Ringo Starr of the bird world also a 'master sculptor', researchers find

image.altText: Tatusya Amano smiling outside

items.synopsis: English is the common language of science, but it comes with downsides for scientists and our planet.

title.children: 'You need to be really brave': Tatsuya took a long time to feel comfortable giving scientific presentations in English

image.altText: A man in a black suit leans into a microphone on a desk.

items.synopsis: Royal commissioner Nick Kaldas says he has "still not identified any strong evidence" to suggest defence is prioritising the mental health of its people in a sustainable way.

title.children: Veteran suicides royal commissioner accuses military brass of waiting to return to 'business as usual'

image.altText: An island with white sandy beaches, turquoise water, swaying palms and blue sky.

items.synopsis: Small island countries say they are sick of "empty promises" and want legally binding obligations clearly spelled out for major polluters at the International Tribunal on the Law of the Sea.

title.children: 'The science is clear and undisputed': Pacific nations bring climate change case at international court

image.altText: A black cylindrical probe is dropped from the back of a helicopter into the ocean.

items.synopsis: The biggest glacier in East Antarctica is slowly melting. A helicopter expedition has paved the way for new methods to test what is causing it.

title.children: Helicopter mission drops probes into Antarctic sea ice cracks — confirming long-held theory about melting

image.altText: A young girl with flowers in her hair stands holding a doll next to her mother

items.synopsis: A trial of a medical technique from Australia that aims to expand the lungs and improve oxygen levels in premature babies finds respiratory-related hospitalisations are reduced by a third.

title.children: It's known as the 'Hobart method' — and it's been adopted worldwide to help premature babies like Eva
